additions.definition: The family as the original, everyday version of communism - 'not in a manifesto, it's in the kitchen' - where 'from each according to ability, to each according to need' is lived out before anyone reads about it in a history book
additions.builds_on: Communism (as family) concept, giving it narrative identity
additions.purpose: Chapter 3 title and central metaphor - makes the claim that family IS communism at proper scale
additions.key_quote: The first little commune is not in a manifesto. It's in the kitchen.

additions.definition: The attempt to scale family operating system to national or corporate level using 'we're a family here' language, which produces three pathologies: paternalism/infantilization, nepotism/dynasties, and unfairness to outsiders
additions.builds_on: Scale Error concept applied to family-to-nation transfer
pathologies: Paternalism/Infantilization: Leaders make decisions FOR citizens like parents for children - 'Children actually need this. Citizens do not.'
Nepotism/Dynasties: 'Jobs go to cousins. Contracts go to in-laws.' Family partiality becomes corruption
Unfairness to Outsiders: Resources flow first to 'our people' - 'What began as a promise of solidarity turns into a justification for favoritism'
additions.purpose: Diagnoses why 'one big family' rhetoric is dangerous at scale
additions.first_mention: Chapter 3, 'The Trouble with One Big Family' section

additions.definition: The hard boundaries of what family-scale communism can accomplish: cannot organize city-wide fire response, coordinate traffic for ambulances, create neutral dispute resolution for strangers, or protect people who have no family to love them
additions.purpose: Sets up transition to socialism/safety habitat in Chapter 4
key_examples: A family cannot keep fire trucks fueled, crews trained, hydrants maintained
A family cannot build and maintain roads for ambulances
A family cannot ensure protection for the person who lives alone and has no relatives
additions.first_mention: Chapter 3, 'What the Commune Can't Do' section

chapter_themes: The family as 'the first little commune' - everyday communism before ideology
Five ingredients that make family communism work (thick love, asymmetric responsibility, intimacy, long horizons, thick 'we')
Two failure modes: too transactional vs too smothering
Why scaling family to nation fails: paternalism, nepotism, exclusion
Special duties vs general duties - when partiality is virtue vs vice
Limits of family: cannot protect strangers, cannot organize public services
Setup for Chapter 4: systems that show up for everyone, not just loved ones
entities_merely_mentioned: Karl Marx - mentioned as source of slogan, not developed as entity
Friedrich Hayek - mentioned re: local knowledge, not developed as entity

extraction_notes.chapter_narrative_role: Chapter 3 provides the deep dive into family as the first habitat where 'from each / to each' makes sense. It names the pattern ('first little commune'), explains why it works (five ingredients), shows how it fails (transactional/smothering, one big family fallacy), and sets up the transition to Chapter 4 by asking: 'what do we call this other system that sends out fire trucks... no matter who we are?'
